title: The Chase's Vixen almost auditioned for X Factor's first series
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

The Chase’s Vixen has admitted she ‘chickened out’ of auditioning for the first ever series of the X Factor ahead of her appearance on the celebrity version of the show.

Turns out she’s got some pipes.

The star – real name Jenny Ryan – is set to show off her singing skills to music mogul Simon Cowell – but it’s actually not her first experience with the show.

Chatting on Good Morning Britain, Jenny admitted she went along to audition for the first ever series.

‘I turned up and I saw the queue was round the building and I went home. I chickened out entirely,’ she laughed.

Advertisement

Advertisement

She admitted she didn’t know if the show would last for more the one series, acknowledging in hindsight that it’s ‘still very much a part of the Saturday night routine.’

The Vixen is one of The Chase’s ruthless Chasers (Picture: ITV)

Reflecting on her feelings at the time, she said: ‘I thought I was an alright singer,’ but went on to say she doesn’t think she was good enough.

However, Jenny is adamant that her alter-ego, The Vixen, has helped her along the way.

‘The way I’ve managed to control my nerves is something that can definitely translate,’ she explained.

‘At the audition stage…it was the Vixen that pushed me out the door and onto the stage.’

While X Factor: Celebrity is being kept pretty under wraps, Jenny teased that fans ‘will see a very different side of me.’

We can’t wait.

Former Love Island contestants Samira Mighty, Zara McDermott, Wes Nelson and Eyal Booker will make up The Islanders, and will be in the groups category for the show.

Also appearing are Towie star Megan McKenna, soap star Jonny Labey, and – possibly the best signing – legendary talk show host Ricki Lake.

Meanwhile, Simon will be joined by Louis Walsh and Nicole Scherzinger who are getting back into their judging seats.

To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Viewers are a little unsure of what to expect from the show – especially after some beloved segments have been abandoned.

Advertisement

Advertisement

In the new series viewers won’t get to see with the boot camp stage or the incredibly tense six chair challenge.

Louis explained: ‘What we’re doing this year I think is a brilliant idea. I think everyone’s going to love watching these celebrities because it’s not what people expect.

‘Some of them are really good. The show feels more exciting. There’s no Bootcamp, no Six-Chair Challenge, it feels slick this year.

‘It’s been the best show on TV for a long time and has just had a little rebranding, I suppose, a new X Factor.’

Good Morning Britain airs every weekday at 6am on ITV1.

description: The Chase's Vixen (Jenny Ryan) 'chickened out' of auditioning for X Factor's first series ahead of X Factor: Celebrity
